englishTranslation: Are you saying that we can go today?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ayer estuvo aquí tres horas, por eso era tarde cuando nos fuimos.
englishTranslation: Yesterday he was here for three hours; that's why it was late when we left.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Dicen que les dijimos que fueran.
englishTranslation: They are saying that we told them to go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
fueran: "were", "they were" (Ser, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Dile que vaya después de la fiesta.
englishTranslation: Tell him to go after the party.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dime si quieres hacerlo mientras yo lo hago.
englishTranslation: Tell me if you want to do it while I do it.

spanishExample: Eso es lo que yo decía después.
englishTranslation: That’s what I was saying afterwards.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Le dijiste que lo hiciera aquí antes.
englishTranslation: You told him to do it here beforehand.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: No estoy seguro de que diga la verdad.
englishTranslation: I’m not sure(m) she is telling the truth.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: No quiere que sus hijos digan lo que ella dijo.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want her kids to say what she said.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Nos dijeron que todavía no lo tenían.
englishTranslation: They told us they still didn’t have it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Quiere que se lo digamos, entonces lo haremos mañana.
englishTranslation: She wants us to tell it to him, so we’ll do it tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Siempre decimos la verdad, entonces la diremos antes de ese día.
englishTranslation: We always tell the truth, so we’ll say it(f) before that day.
vocabIncluded: diremos: "will say", "we will say" (Decir, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Te dije que eso es lo que ella dice.
englishTranslation: I told you that that’s what she says.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tengo que decirte que no digas nada.
englishTranslation: I have to tell you not to say anything.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Voy a decirle que vaya luego.
englishTranslation: I’m going to tell her to go later.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
